item.title: What to Know About the U.S. Attacks on Iran
item.content:encoded: The United States and Israel launched a major assault, as President Trump called on Iranians to overthrow the government.

item.title: Chaos and Panic Grip Tehran as Airstrikes Shake City
item.content:encoded: Iranians were beginning their workweek as U.S. and Israeli strikes sent people fleeing parts of the capital and parents racing to collect children from schools.

item.title: OpenAI Reaches A.I. Agreement With Defense Dept. After Anthropic Clash
item.content:encoded: The deal came hours after President Trump had ordered federal agencies to stop using artificial intelligence technology made by Anthropic, an OpenAI rival.

item.title: The President of War
item.content:encoded: The U.S. military was once a tool of last resort for American presidents.

item.title: Berkshire Hathaway Posts a Drop in Earnings in Buffett’s Last Year
item.content:encoded: In his first report as C.E.O., Gregory Abel, stuck to a straight commentary rather than Warren Buffett’s folksy tone. The lower earnings were largely driven by declines in the insurance business.

item.title: Berkshire Hathaway Posts a Drop in Earnings in Buffett’s Last Year
item.content:encoded: In his first report as C.E.O., Gregory Abel, stuck to a straight commentary rather than Warren Buffett’s folksy tone. The lower earnings were largely driven by declines in the insurance business.

item.title: Why Have You Started This War, Mr. President?
item.content:encoded: Donald Trump promised voters that he would end wars, not start them.

item.title: The United States and Israel Attack Iran
item.content:encoded: The country is retaliating, and the Middle East is in crisis.

item.title: Banks Are Becoming Bulwarks for Vulnerable Seniors
item.content:encoded: Older Americans are losing billions of dollars annually to financial exploitation. Banks and investment firms are training employees to spot red flags and stop the transactions.

item.title: How David Zaslav Pulled Off the Sale of Warner Bros. Discovery to Paramount
item.content:encoded: Not long ago, Mr. Zaslav was widely criticized for his management of Warner Bros. Discovery. He overcame the doubters, cementing a blockbuster sale to Paramount.

item.title: Lloyd Blankfein on Trump, Epstein and Life After Goldman Sachs
item.content:encoded: In a wide-ranging interview with Andrew Ross Sorkin, Goldman’s former C.E.O. discussed his life and new memoir.

item.title: Lloyd Blankfein on Trump, Epstein and Life After Goldman Sachs
item.content:encoded: In a wide-ranging interview with Andrew Ross Sorkin, Goldman’s former C.E.O. discussed his life and new memoir.

item.title: How The Times Covers Cartels and Other Criminal Enterprises
item.content:encoded: Cultivating sources. Verifying claims. Staying safe. After the death of El Mencho, four journalists share their approach to this difficult, dangerous work.

item.title: Netflix Lost Warner. Maybe That’s a Good Thing.
item.content:encoded: It is entirely possible, analysts say, that Netflix will be better off by bailing from its $83 billion deal with Warner Bros. Discovery.

item.title: Netflix Lost Warner. Maybe That’s a Good Thing.
item.content:encoded: It is entirely possible, analysts say, that Netflix will be better off by bailing from its $83 billion deal with Warner Bros. Discovery.

item.title: The Bloody Rise and Fall of Mexico’s Top Crime Boss
item.content:encoded: El Mencho’s brutality and business acumen put him atop the cartel world, until he made a fatal mistake.

item.title: Abrupt Change for Warner Bros. Prompts Many Grim Faces
item.content:encoded: Employees at the company had started to warm to the idea of Netflix as its corporate owner. Now they face the prospect of major cuts under Paramount.

item.title: Abrupt Change for Warner Bros. Prompts Many Grim Faces
item.content:encoded: Employees at the company had started to warm to the idea of Netflix as its corporate owner. Now they face the prospect of major cuts under Paramount.

item.title: Pentagon Watchdog Stalls Proposal to Review Targeting in Trump’s Boat Strikes
item.content:encoded: A new inspector general delayed a decision on whether to approve the project and is said to have raised its potential political ramifications, in a test of the watchdog system in President Trump’s second term.

item.title: QAnon Faithful See Validation in the Epstein Files
item.content:encoded: The nearly decade-old conspiracy theory does not align neatly with the facts emerging from the documents. That does not seem to matter.

item.title: 4 Ways to Enjoy Your Savings in Retirement Without Going Broke
item.content:encoded: Once paychecks stop, it can be frightening to shift out of the savings habit. But there are strategies to enjoy your nest egg and make it last.

item.title: A Tale of Two Seasons at Columbia, and Two Responses to Student Arrests
item.content:encoded: When Mahmoud Khalil was detained by immigration agents last year, the university’s response was restrained. It was different with Elmina Aghayeva this week.

item.title: New Geothermal Technology Aims to Produce Clean Energy in Germany
item.content:encoded: Developers are using a new geothermal technology in Germany to produce clean energy.

item.title: Justice Dept. Tries to Slow Down Legal Battle Over Tariff Refunds
item.content:encoded: Earlier, President Trump suggested on social media that he could try to persuade the Supreme Court to reconsider its rejection of his tariffs.

item.title: Instagram to Alert Parents to Teens’ Self-Harm Searches
item.content:encoded: Parents will receive notifications if a child has used the platform repeatedly to search for terms related to suicide or self-harm, but users must opt in to get them.

item.title: In a Memoir Draft, Changpeng Zhao of Binance Details the Talks Leading to His Prison Time
item.content:encoded: In a draft of his memoir, Changpeng Zhao, the founder of Binance, laid out the secret negotiations that led to his imprisonment and a run-in with ICE.

item.title: Taiwan Arms Sale Approved by Congress Is Delayed as Trump Plans Visit to Beijing
item.content:encoded: The package worth billions of dollars and endorsed by lawmakers is stalled at the State Department as the U.S. and China plan an April summit.

item.title: Iris Cantor, Philanthropist and Art Collector, Dies at 95
item.content:encoded: She and her husband, the financier B. Gerald Cantor, amassed one of the largest private collections of Rodin artworks, donating much of it to museums around the world.

item.title: For CNN, a Takeover by Paramount Means a Suddenly Uncertain Future
item.content:encoded: Paramount’s apparent victory over Netflix in securing Warner Bros. Discovery has led to concerns within the CNN newsroom about editorial independence.

item.title: Pentagon-Anthropic Standoff Is a Decisive Moment for How A.I. Will Be Used in War
item.content:encoded: The Pentagon’s contract dispute with Anthropic is part of a wider clash about the use of artificial intelligence for national security and who decides on any safeguards.

item.title: Trump Media Explores Spinning Off Truth Social
item.content:encoded: The move would split off the money-losing social media platform as the company pursues a merger with a fusion power company.

item.title: OpenAI Raises $110 Billion Led by Amazon, Nvidia and SoftBank, Extending A.I. Boom
item.content:encoded: Amazon, Nvidia and SoftBank led the investment, valuing the parent of ChatGPT at $730 billion.

item.title: How India Became One of the World’s Biggest Economies
item.content:encoded: India has grown rapidly despite its slow industrialization, and its economy is now nearly as big as Japan’s.

item.title: With a New Nigeria Refinery, Africa’s Richest Man Wants ‘to Rescue the Country’
item.content:encoded: Aliko Dangote, Africa’s richest man, has an ambitious vision for the continent’s most populous nation, but hurdles stand in his way.

item.title: Overlooked No More: Bobby Garnett, ‘Godfather’ of Vintage Dealers
item.content:encoded: His store, Bobby From Boston, transformed the way vintage men’s wear is sold, serving as a model for a generation of retailers.

item.title: Netflix Backs Out of Bid for Warner Bros., Paving Way for Paramount Takeover
item.content:encoded: The move was a stunning development in the long-running corporate battle for the storied media giant.

item.title: What Larry and David Ellison Would Own After Warner Bros. Takeover
item.content:encoded: If Paramount can close its deal to buy Warner Bros. Discovery, Larry and David Ellison will influence nearly every corner of news, entertainment and tech.

item.title: New A.C.A. Plans Could Increase Family Deductibles to $31,000
item.content:encoded: The Trump administration is proposing Obamacare plans that it says will lower health insurance premiums. But critics warn they would make care unaffordable.

item.title: Germany’s Oil and Gas Output Is Dwindling as Prices Rise
item.content:encoded: Natural gas production in Germany has fallen about 80 percent in the past two decades even as the country seeks to replace flows from Russia.

item.title: E.U. Pushes Ahead With South American Trade Deal Despite Legal Challenge
item.content:encoded: The provisional application of the agreement with Brazil, Argentina, Paraguay and Uruguay is intended to diversify Europe’s trading relationships.

item.title: The I.R.S. Shut Its Direct File, but Here Are Other Free Filing Options
item.content:encoded: The agency still offers a Free File program that works with commercial tax software firms. Some companies also offer free tools for certain filers.

item.title: Paramount Is Set to Win Warner Bros. Now Comes the Hard Part.
item.content:encoded: The media company controlled by the Ellisons out-dueled Netflix for control of Warner Bros. Discovery. The next step is making the combined media empires work.

item.title: He Hopes to Turn the Island of Nevis Into a Libertarian Paradise, With Crypto
item.content:encoded: A Bitcoin baron wants to build a libertarian paradise on the island of Nevis. Democracy is getting in the way.

item.title: South Korea Clears Way for Google Maps to Fully Operate
item.content:encoded: South Korea approved Google’s request to export detailed map data, reversing a longstanding restriction that made the tool largely nonfunctional.

item.title: A World Where All Is Free? That’s Elon Musk’s Theory of ‘Sustainable Abundance.’
item.content:encoded: The Tesla and SpaceX chief has told his followers that they will live in a world where robots will take care of every need and people do not have to work, in what has become his latest slogan.

item.title: Fighting Wildfires Could Soon Get Harder
item.content:encoded: Simultaneous emergencies in different parts of the world could stop countries from sharing ground crews and equipment, new research warns.

item.title: The Web of Companies Owned by Elon Musk
item.content:encoded: In mapping out Elon Musk’s wealth, our investigation found that Mr. Musk is behind more than 90 companies in Texas. Kirsten Grind, a New York Times Investigations reporter, explains what her team found.

item.title: The Rise and Fall of a 3-D Printing Empire
item.content:encoded: Desktop Metal, a billion-dollar start-up, promised to revolutionize manufacturing. It went bankrupt, and now has much humbler ambitions as the 3-D printing industry takes a sober turn.

item.title: Elon Musk’s Secret Web of Companies in Texas
item.content:encoded: The megabillionaire was tied to about 90 companies in the state, which he uses for everything from paying nannies to buying land to supporting Donald Trump’s re-election, according to a Times examination.

item.title: Honolulu on a Budget
item.content:encoded: Hawaii is expensive, but basing yourself in the capital, where local culture and nature are within easy reach, can save you money on lodgings and food, leaving funds for a few splurges.

item.title: How a Close Associate of Epstein’s Found Career Redemption in Japan
item.content:encoded: Top Japanese officials are backing a tech and entrepreneurship initiative led in part by Joichi Ito, whose involvement with Jeffrey Epstein may endanger efforts to get the project off the ground.

item.title: India Built the World’s Back Office. A.I. Is Starting to Shrink It.
item.content:encoded: Artificial intelligence promises to automate the white-collar work that made India a tech powerhouse. The country is racing to adapt before it’s too late.

item.title: Block Cuts 40% of Its Work Force Because of Its Embrace of A.I.
item.content:encoded: About 4,000 workers will lose their jobs as the payments company does more work with new artificial intelligence tools, its top executive said.

item.title: 32.6 Million Watched Trump’s State of the Union Address, Nielsen Says
item.content:encoded: The audience was roughly on par with former President Biden’s final State of the Union address in 2024.

item.title: Why Estrogen Patches For Menopause Are So Hard to Find
item.content:encoded: Changing attitudes around menopause treatment have driven up demand for hormone therapy.

item.title: U.S. Mortgage Rates Fall Below 6% for First Time in Years
item.content:encoded: The evidence is patchy on whether lower rates have meaningfully spurred more activity, as the Trump administration floats measures it says will make housing more affordable.

item.title: World Economic Forum Chief Resigns Over Epstein Ties
item.content:encoded: Borge Brende, a former foreign minister of Norway, had maintained contact with the convicted sex offender.

item.title: Oliver Grant, a Business Architect of the Wu-Tang Clan, Dies
item.content:encoded: He was behind the scenes with Wu-Tang Clan, the New York rap group, since its founding and helped expand its reach with a fashion line.

item.title: FedEx Says It Could Return Tariff Refunds to Customers
item.content:encoded: The company sued the administration days after the Supreme Court ruled against the president’s duties.

item.title: Z? Zo? Mam? Mayor Zohran Mamdani is a Man of Many Nicknames.
item.content:encoded: Mayor Zohran Mamdani has been given a bevy of nicknames by New York City’s tabloid newspapers and political class. Which will stick?

item.title: They Helped Women Fight Online Abuse. They Were Barred From the U.S.
item.content:encoded: The founders of HateAid, a German human-rights group that helps victims of online attacks, were accused by the Trump administration of being part of a “global censorship-industrial complex.”

item.title: Kalshi Accuses a ‘MrBeast’ Employee of Insider Trading
item.content:encoded: The prediction-market platform said it had reported the employee to federal regulators. The show’s parent company said it had “no tolerance for this behavior.”

item.title: Why Nvidia’s Big Profits Aren’t Lifting Markets
item.content:encoded: The chip giant at the center of the artificial intelligence boom again beat expectations. But it didn’t overcome investor jitters.

item.title: Revel, a Maker of Software for Running Hardware, Raises $150 Million
item.content:encoded: The start-up, founded by a former top SpaceX engineer, promises to help companies reduce their testing times and optimize systems.

item.title: A.I. Dating Apps Complicate China’s Efforts to Boost Birthrate
item.content:encoded: As China grapples with a shrinking population and historically low birthrate, people are finding romance with chatbots instead.
